column1: Martha! now came her husband's impatient voice. "Don't keep folks waiting out here in the cold."She again opened the storm-door
column2: and this time joined the three men and the one woman waiting for her in the big two-seated buggy.After she had the robes tucked around her she took another look at the woman who sat beside her on the back seat. She had met Mrs. Peters the year before at the county fair
column3: and the thing she remembered about her was that she didn't seem like a sheriff's wife. She was small and thin and didn't have a strong voice. Mrs. Gorman
column4: sheriff's wife before Gorman went out and Peters came in
column5: had a voice that somehow seemed to be backing up the law with every word. But if Mrs. Peters didn't look like a sheriff's wife
column6: Peters made it up in looking like a sheriff. He was to a dot the kind of man who could get himself elected sheriff — a heavy man with a big voice
column7: who was particularly genial with the law-abiding
column8: as if to make it plain that he knew the difference between criminals and non-criminals.
